author: By Peter Baker
title: A Year Later, Jan. 6 Becomes Just Another Wedge in a Divided Nation
description: The nearly universal outrage after the assault on the Capitol has reverted to separate blue and red realities, and former President Donald J. Trump has remained the dominant force in his party.
content: WASHINGTON — For a day or two or maybe a week after the can-you-believe-this-is-happening-in-America events of a year ago, there were those who thought that the shock to the system might upend politics in a profound way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: In ‘African Origin’ Show at Met, New Points of Light Across Cultures
description: Holdings from Ancient Egypt and sub-Saharan Africa come together in a masterpiece show. Now the Met should make clear how the wondrous works got here.
content: Object for object, there isn’t an exhibition in town more beautiful than “The African Origin of Civilization” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Nor is there one more shot through with ethical and political tensions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: Why Novak Djokovic Was Blocked From Entering Australia
description: The men’s No. 1 tennis player had received an exemption to the country’s vaccine requirements. Then the federal government stepped in.
content: Novak Djokovic, the top player in men’s tennis and its leading vaccine skeptic, was stopped at the border in Melbourne late Wednesday after flying from Dubai to defend his Australian Open title.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Shaman
title: Here’s When We Expect Omicron to Peak
description: An epidemic modeler explains why cases of the variant will peak in the U.S. in January.
content: The Omicron variant is spreading widely and infecting large numbers of people, including the vaccinated and those previously infected with the virus. While spikes in cases have been the norm for the past two years, there are clear indications this wave will differ substantially from previous ones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: One Year Later, Congress Weighs How to Memorialize Jan. 6 at the Capitol
description: In a building that is both a legislative body and a living museum, lawmakers are grappling with how to commemorate an attack whose victims cannot agree on the basic facts of the day.
content: Follow our live updates on the Jan. 6 Capitol Attack anniversary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Federal Prisons Director Is Resigning After Rocky Tenure
description: Michael Carvajal took over the Bureau of Prisons in February 2020, just as the coronavirus began to sweep through the nation’s prisons.
content: WASHINGTON — The head of the Federal Bureau of Prisons plans to resign as the agency struggles with issues that have overshadowed his tenure, including employee misconduct, understaffing and violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Women’s Periods May Be Late After Coronavirus Vaccination, Study Suggests
description: An analysis of thousands of menstrual records offers support for anecdotal reports of erratic cycles after shots.
content: Shortly after coronavirus vaccines were rolled out about a year ago, women started reporting erratic menstrual cycles after receiving the shots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Manhattan D.A. Acts on Vow to Seek Incarceration Only for Worst Crimes
description: Alvin Bragg has told prosecutors in his office to seek jail or prison time for only the most serious crimes, unless the law requires otherwise.
content: Manhattan’s new district attorney began this week to adopt the lenient policies he campaigned on, setting the stage for potential conflict inside and outside his office as he tries to change the way criminal justice is administered in the borough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Soller
title: Sex, Death and Polaroids
description: Clifton Mooney came to New York to be a Covid nurse. After hours, he embraced life by taking intimate pictures of his friends.
content: It was a Hot Vax June quickly becoming a Delta Variant July soon to mutate into whatever August was (who can recall at this point?), and there was Clifton Mooney, a 1976 Polaroid SX-70 camera dangling on a nylon strap from his neck — the only part of his body, except his face, that isn’t heavily tattooed — clutching a beer, as hazy and bright as the afternoon sun blazing down onto the shirtless, gay New York City men around him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Google Infringed on Sonos Speaker Technology, Trade Court Rules
description: The company will not be allowed to import products that infringe on Sonos patents, including smart speakers, video streaming devices, and some computers and phones.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — Google infringed on five audio technology patents held by the speaker manufacturer Sonos and is not allowed to import products that violate Sonos’s intellectual property into the United States, a trade court ruled on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By LaChanze
title: LaChanze on the Personal Resonance of Alice Childress’s Timeless Words
description: Since October, the actress has been performing the lead role of Wiletta Mayer in the Broadway debut of Childress’s 1955 play “Trouble in Mind.”
content: “I started to scream but no sound come out … just a screamin’ but no sound …”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claudia Gryvatz Copquin and Lisa Prevost
title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: This week’s homes are a four-bedroom in Westport, Conn., and a three-bedroom in Massapequa, N.Y.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. Ross Flatt
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Chasing the Truth: A Young Journalist’s Guide to Investigative Reporting’
description: In this lesson, students will learn how two Times journalists helped ignite the #MeToo movement. Then, we invite students to join a live Jan. 27 panel with the journalists and ask them questions.
content: Note: This Lesson of the Day, along with a related Student Opinion prompt, “What Do You Want to Investigate?,” will help prepare students for our live panel with Jodi Kantor and Megan Twohey on Jan. 27. Register here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: The Cheneys, once despised by the left, are welcomed warmly by Democrats at a Jan. 6 observance.
description: “The future of the country is at stake, and there are moments when we all have to come together in order to defend the Constitution,” Representative Liz Cheney, Republican of Wyoming, said.
content: There were just two Republicans present in the House chamber for a moment of silence commemorating the Jan. 6 riot in the Capitol: Representative Liz Cheney of Wyoming, and her father, Dick Cheney, the former vice president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: A School Won 92-4 in Basketball. Then the Coach Was Suspended.
description: Sacred Heart Academy, a Catholic high school for girls in Hamden, Conn., said that running up the score against Lyman Hall High School did not mesh with its values.
content: The scoreboard, stuck on zero for the visiting team until the game’s final quarter, wasn’t broken.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Will ‘Forever Boosting’ Beat the Coronavirus?
description: Everyone should get a booster shot. In the long run, though, doses every few months aren’t a viable public health strategy, scientists say.
content: A year ago, just two doses of a Covid-19 vaccine — or even one, in the case of Johnson & Johnson’s formulation — were thought to offer sufficient protection against the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: How Many Americans Support Political Violence?
description: Probably a lot fewer than you’ve been led to believe, but more than enough to make you nervous.
content: Follow our live updates on the Jan. 6 Capitol Attack Anniversary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: The Mets Found a Hitting Coach. He Was on the Yankees’ Bench.
description: Eric Chavez was named an assistant hitting coach for the Yankees just last month, but he will move across town to guide Mets hitters instead.
content: Although the lockout in Major League Baseball continues deep into the off-season, the Mets have been busy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Harmon
title: Is Covid Causing Decision Fatigue? Share Your Story.
description: We want to hear from you.
content: For almost two years, the coronavirus has forced us all to make decisions — large and small — as we decide how to move forward. Omicron, like earlier variants, has brought new circumstances and a new set of considerations when it comes to those decisions. Should I send my children to school? Should I wear a higher-grade mask? Should I stay away from public places or resign myself to getting this latest variant?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Ashley Wong
title: As Omicron Infects Workers, Subway Service Suffers
description: With coronavirus cases surging in New York, about 21 percent of subway operators and conductors were absent this week, causing suspensions on three lines and changed schedules on others.
content: As a dizzying surge in coronavirus cases spurred by the fast-spreading Omicron variant has disrupted life in New York City and undermined its economic recovery, its subway system — the nation’s largest — has confronted a staggering worker shortage that has hampered its ability to keep trains running.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Hochul’s Priorities: Lift the Economy and Attract Health Workers
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul’s first State of the State address called for dozens of initiatives as she prepares to run for a full term as governor.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll look at the policy proposals Gov. Kathy Hochul outlined in her State of the State message. We’ll also look at whether there is friction between Mayor Eric Adams and the Manhattan district attorney, Alvin Bragg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch, Kevin Draper and Katherine Rosman
title: New York Times Co. to Buy The Athletic for $550 Million in Cash
description: The deal could help the media company reach its goal of 10 million subscriptions ahead of schedule.
content: The New York Times Company has reached an agreement to buy The Athletic, the online sports news outlet with 1.2 million subscriptions, in an all-cash deal valued at $550 million, The Times said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Brennan, Simon Romero and Erin Schaff
title: ‘I Have Absolutely Nothing’: After a Massive Winter Fire, What Is Left?
description: Families whose homes were left in ashes when the Marshall fire swept around Boulder, Colo., now face starting over again in a housing market that was competitive even before hundreds of homes were destroyed.
content: LOUISVILLE, Colo. — Bryan Giles, who fled with his cat, Chloe, finds himself replaying their harrowing escape from the blaze. The Manz family is scouring the ruins of their home for family heirlooms. Nan Boultbee and Lex Kell are still waiting for their street to reopen to catch a glimpse of the four-bedroom house they had lived in for five years, now torched.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Expedition Content’ Review: Anthropological Maneuvers in the Dark
description: An engrossing documentary looks back at a 1961 expedition to New Guinea and the creation of the landmark ethnographic film that resulted.
content: “But what to do with your eyes?” — this ridiculous question popped into my head early while watching “Expedition Content,” though watching doesn’t entirely describe what I was doing. I was listening, a lot. That’s because for most of its 78 minutes, this startling and fascinating experimental documentary shows you only a black screen. Every so often, a shock of slate-y, steely blue fills the frame, followed by text. Late in the work, there is a cut to a brief scene that was shot from inside a cave. There, silhouetted figures carrying torches move about, faintly illuminated by light from the mouth of the cave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: ‘Emily in Paris’ Isn’t the Only Clichéd Show in This Town
description: Netflix doesn’t qualify as a solo offender when it comes to Gallic stereotypes, as three musical theater works on the city’s stages show.
content: PARIS — There’s been no shortage of complaints from Parisians about the Netflix series “Emily in Paris.” Yet an endless stream of clichés about the city — from cafes by the Louvre to chain smoking and ménages à trois — isn’t merely the province of Americans. French artists indulge, too; at home, however, rose-tinted nostalgia hits differently.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: The new year offers a handy excuse, as if you needed one, to broaden your literary horizons: Maybe read that neglected classic, or the best seller you didn’t get to when everyone was talking about it, or the serious nonfiction book that will finally help you understand monetary policy or black holes or the relationship between monetary policy and black holes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Jan. 6 Panel Faces Difficult Questions as Anniversary of Capitol Riot Approaches’
description: In this lesson, students will explore how Congress is investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, and then they will form their own committee to uncover what happened that day and what we can learn from it.
content: Featured Article: “Jan. 6 Panel Faces Difficult Questions as Anniversary of Capitol Riot Approaches” by Luke Broadwater and Emily Cochrane
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sohrab Ahmari
title: Jan. 6 Looks Different Through the Lens of ‘American Carnage’
description: The nation has festering problems. Trumpism  did not go to the true roots of them.
content: This article is part of a collection on the events of Jan. 6, one year later. Read more in a note from Times Opinion’s politics editor Ezekiel Kweku in our Opinion Today newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The fight over American democracy and the fragility of good faith: A discussion with Times reporters.
description: Our political journalists talked about the Republican push to restrict voting and seize control over elections, and how Democrats are responding.
content: Our political journalists talked about the G.O.P.’s push to restrict voting and seize control over elections, and how Democrats are responding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Teenagers in The Times: December 2021
description: Our roundup of the news stories and features about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com.
content: Here is the December, 2021 edition of Teenagers in The Times, a roundup of the news and feature stories about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com. We publish a new edition on the first Thursday of each month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: Let Marjorie Taylor Greene Keep Her Social Media Accounts
description: We’ve ceded too much control over our speech to Big Tech.
content: This past weekend, when Twitter permanently suspended the personal account of Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, a Republican of Georgia, her offenses were clear: She had repeatedly posted misinformation about Covid and vaccines, violating Twitter’s rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wendy Parmet
title: The Government’s Ability to Control the Pandemic Is at Stake
description: Biden’s vaccine mandates must remain intact.
content: On Friday, the Supreme Court will hear oral arguments about two of the Biden administration’s emergency Covid-19 regulations, including a vaccine or test mandate for large employers and a vaccine requirement for some health workers. At stake in the cases, brought by business groups and Republican-led states, is not only the future of the pandemic but also the federal government’s capacity to respond to continuing and future health threats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: ‘Rigoletto’ at the Met Unites a Father and Daughter. Again.
description: Quinn Kelsey and Rosa Feola have earned raves playing a jester and his child in a new production of Verdi’s opera.
content: Quinn Kelsey and Rosa Feola are used to playing father and daughter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Hands
description: What message do you think this image is communicating?
content: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Film Club: ‘Grieving Our Old Normal’
description: How do we mourn everything we’ve lost to Covid?
content: “Grieving Our Old Normal” is a four-minute film that touches on themes of loss, acceptance and our all-too-human struggle to make sense of life in a pandemic and all that we can never get back. In this Opinion video, Lindsay Crouse, one of the filmmakers, asks us to reckon with a new, cold reality: After all of the deaths, the canceled weddings, the lonely birthday celebrations, the boredom and the terror, “There is no going back to normal. Your old life is gone. But whether you wanted to or not, you were building a new one. You still are. What do you want your new life to be?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: China’s Latest Lockdown Shows Stubborn Resolve on Zero-Covid
description: Xi’an, a city of 13 million people, has been on lockdown since Dec. 22, the longest in the country since the early days of the outbreak in Wuhan.
content: Every two days at the University of Xi’an in China, cleaners dressed in white hazmat suits taped tight to their bodies disinfect the dormitory hallways. Zhang Shengzi, a 24-year-old student, said the smell is so pungent she has to wait some time after they’ve gone before she will open her door again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope Scolds Couples Who Choose Pets Over Kids
description: Expressing concern about global birthrates, Francis said such couples were acting in a selfish way that diminished humanity.
content: ROME — Pope Francis has not been reluctant to offer his views on polarizing subjects, but on Wednesday, he waded into an issue involving two subjects on which consensus is almost impossible to find.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: A Fed Official’s 2020 Trade Drew Outcry. It Went Further Than First Disclosed.
description: Corrected disclosures show that Vice Chair Richard H. Clarida sold a stock fund, then swiftly repurchased it before a big Fed announcement.
content: Richard H. Clarida, the departing vice chair of the Federal Reserve, failed to initially disclose the extent of a financial transaction he made in early 2020 as the Fed was preparing to swoop in and rescue markets amid the unfolding pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Jan. 6 Riot, Kazakhstan, Peter Bogdanovich: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Berk
title: A Custom Mercury, With a Batmobile in Its Family Tree, Heads to Auction
description: The “Hirohata Merc,” commissioned in 1952 and one of the most famous custom cars of its era, is up for sale for the first time in over 60 years.
content: Nearly 70 years ago, a 21-year-old Navy veteran commissioned a custom Mercury, with a chopped-down roof, smoothed-out body panels, a lowered stance, novel chrome trim, two-tone paint and a meticulously handcrafted interior. It was built by the same shop that would later create the Batmobile for the “Batman” TV series, and James Dean’s Merc in “Rebel Without a Cause” cut a similar style.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: That $1,000 Bourbon You Bought May Be a Phony
description: Counterfeiting — filling luxury bottles with cheap liquor — has hit American whiskey hard as sky-high prices raise the payoff for scammers.
content: To the casual eye, there was nothing amiss about the bottle of whiskey sitting on a shelf at Acker, a wine store on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. But for anyone who knew what to look for, the warning signs were clear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: Cases Rise, Criticism Mounts, but Ships Keep Cruising
description: One day after the C.D.C. advised against all travel on cruise ships, thousands of cruisers partied like it was 2019. But worries about onboard policies — and frustration over quarantines — are rising.
content: On the fourth day of a seven-day Mexican Riviera cruise, Jesse Suphan and other passengers onboard the Carnival Cruise Line’s Panorama were denied entry at the port of Puerto Vallarta, because of the number of onboard coronavirus cases. That was the first Mr. Suphan heard about the virus spreading on the ship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Etel Adnan and Victoria Chang
title: Poem: Untitled
description: Etel Adnan avoids easy understanding or conclusion. She layers on complexity, and we are thrust into the magical unknown.
content: We lost the great Etel Adnan in 2021. I happened to see her exhibit at the Guggenheim Museum in New York on the same day that she died. Adnan’s poems seem to work like her paintings — images pile on top of one another, making new shapes that are more tonal than definitional. At the end of this poem, there’s a choice made when, unspecifically, “the hearts” have “given into violence.” What I love about Adnan’s poems are the ways in which they avoid easy understanding or conclusion. With the addition of “of the wind” at the end of the last line, she layers on complexity, and we are thrust into the magical unknown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Friday Briefing: Biden warns of threats to democracy
description: U.S. lawmakers commemorate last year’s attack on the Capitol.
content: With lawmakers gathered in the Capitol on the anniversary of the Jan. 6 assault on the building by a pro-Trump mob, President Biden denounced Donald Trump for spinning a “web of lies” and threatening democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Republicans for Democracy
description: American democracy may depend on a conservative-liberal alliance.
content: Liz Cheney opposes most abortions and most gun control. She favors tax cuts for the wealthy and expanded drilling for oil. The right-wing Family Research Council has given her voting record a perfect score. Her political hero is her hawkish father, who was the architect of the second Iraq War.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: To Reach South Korea, He Risked His Life. To Leave It, He Did It Again.
description: Officials say a North Korean who crossed the DMZ in 2020 crossed it again to go back. His life in the South seems to have been one of poverty and isolation.
content: SEOUL — In November 2020, a North Korean ex-gymnast climbed undetected over 10-foot barbed-wire fences to get into South Korea. When the South belatedly discovered the breach, it began an extensive manhunt. The man was not found until the next day, half a mile south of the world’s most heavily armed border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart A. Thompson
title: On Bannon’s show, Matt Gaetz and Marjorie Taylor Greene redirect blame for the Capitol riot.
description: The idea that people other than Mr. Trump’s own supporters were responsible for the violence that day has become a popular conspiracy theory among the far right.
content: Around the same time President Biden said former President Donald J. Trump encouraged the violence that took place at the Capitol on Jan. 6, some of Mr. Trump’s most prominent supporters deflected blame for the attack during an appearance on a live online show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: What We Know About the Philadelphia Rowhouse Fire
description: Twelve people — three sisters and their sons and daughters — were killed in the blaze, which swept through a building owned by the federally funded Philadelphia Housing Authority.
content: A fire overwhelmed a crowded Philadelphia rowhouse on Wednesday morning, killing three sisters and nine of their sons and daughters in one of the deadliest residential fires in the nation’s recent history.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
description: A Kiki Smith exhibition catalog, wacky hand-tufted rugs — and more.
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘See for Me’ Review: Steal Away
description: A young blind woman is menaced by a crew of robbers in this forgettable thriller.
content: Ever since Audrey Hepburn tiptoed around three home-invading thugs in “Wait Until Dark” (1967), the blind-person-in-peril narrative has been something of an entertainment staple. And while Randall Okita’s “See For Me” offers the novelty of a disabled character who is rather less than morally upstanding, this uninvolving thriller is as lacking in tension as credibility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood
title: In a First for Pakistan, a Woman Is Cleared to Become a Supreme Court Justice
description: Justice Ayesha A. Malik’s nomination, intensely opposed by some lawyers that have threatened to strike, was hailed by others as an important victory in improving representation for women.
content: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan cleared the way for the first woman in the country’s history to become a Supreme Court justice, when a judicial commission on Thursday approved the elevation of Justice Ayesha A. Malik to the top court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Federal Labor Officials Claim New York Times Violated Workplace Law
description: The National Labor Relations Board alleges that Times management wrongly prevented some employees from showing support for a union, a claim the paper denied.
content: The National Labor Relations Board has alleged in a complaint that The New York Times violated federal workplace law by telling some employees that they could not publicly support a recently formed union of tech workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: No running through the house with a pickle in your mouth: “The Righteous Gemstones” is back.
content: ‘The Righteous Gemstones’When to watch: Sunday at 10 p.m., on HBO.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Djokovic Collides With a Difficult Moment in Australia’s Covid Fight
description: Barring the tennis star from entering the country offers a chance to change the subject as an election looms and coronavirus cases are at record highs.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — When Australia’s prime minister explained on Thursday why his government had barred Novak Djokovic, the men’s tennis superstar, from entering the country, he described it as “simply a matter of following the rules” requiring coronavirus vaccinations for incoming travelers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Bringing Home the Rat Juice
description: A woman believes her husband is tracking vermin residue into their apartment.
content: Jeff writes: My wife has a fear of rats that’s getting worse. She now insists that I remove my shoes as soon as I enter our apartment because she believes that anyone who walks in Manhattan gets “rat juice” on their footwear. Please order that there is no such thing and that a vigorous workout on the welcome mat is reasonable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezekiel Kweku
title: The Storming of the Capitol, One Year On
description: Times Opinion puts the events of Jan. 6 in context.
content: This article also appears in the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I texted my editor: Guns drawn.’ Times reporters discuss their experiences inside the Capitol on Jan. 6.
description: Focused on the counting of electoral votes, those inside the building didn’t fully grasp how bad things had gotten outside until it was too late.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Intellectual Conformity
description: A thoughtful New York Times Crossword debut by Andrew Linzer.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Even after all this time, I still get tripped up by the occasional theme. That’s normal. We are supposed to fight our way through a Thursday crossword, and we can’t always be the victor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Where Do Best-Selling Authors Want You to Buy Their Books?
description: Writers are always extolling the virtues of independent bookstores, but sometimes their websites tell a different story.
content: SHOP LOCAL Amor Towles’s third novel, “The Lincoln Highway,” is at No. 4 in its 13th week on the hardcover fiction list. Here’s a small but notable fact about the former Wall Streeter turned full-time writer: He is one of the few best-selling authors whose website sends potential readers to buy books from Indiebound before Amazon. If you’re a publishing geek like me, you’ll notice how many popular writers profess to be grateful to independent bookstores for the success of their novels, memoirs, thrillers, picture books and self-help guides — but mosey over to their personal pages and you’ll find click-to-buy links that whisk you directly to Jeff Bezos’ Everything Store (do not pass an artfully curated front window, do not hear bells chime as you walk in the front door, do not collect a free bookmark by the cash register). Yes, there is the ease of one-click ordering your next read along with your paper towels; yes, if you present purchasing buttons in alphabetical order, Amazon will land at the top of the list. But if you are an author, like Towles, who claims to appreciate local bookshops for “hand selling” your work, why not direct your readers straight to Indiebound, which helps keep the light on in those stores? John Grisham, Mitch Albom, Nicholas Sparks and Diana Gabaldon, I’m looking at you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport, Madeleine Ngo and Kate Kelly
title: Corporations Donated Millions to Lawmakers Who Voted to Overturn Election Results
description: One year after the Capitol riot, many businesses resumed corporate donations to lawmakers who voted against certifying the 2020 election.
content: WASHINGTON — At its annual summit on the state of American business last January, officials from the U.S. Chamber of Commerce expressed disgust at the siege of the Capitol that had unfolded days earlier, and declared that lawmakers who discredited the 2020 election would no longer receive the organization’s financial backing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Canada Bans ‘Conversion Therapy’
description: The law, which takes effect on Friday, puts Canada in the company of more than a dozen countries that have banned the widely discredited practice.
content: A Canadian law banning so-called conversion therapy is poised to go into effect on Friday, making it a crime to provide or promote services intended to change or repress a person’s sexual orientation or gender expression.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually and in person in New York City.
content: This season, as the Omicron variant has either closed cultural institutions or made being inside them less appealing, outdoor light festivals have provided some respite. One standout is “Lightscape” at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. This optical extravaganza — which includes light displays that wind around the grounds for more than a mile, vendors selling snacks and beverages, and poetry by the author Jacqueline Woodson projected at points along the path — is closing on Sunday. Tickets are $34 for adults and $18 for children, and are available at bbg.org. On Fridays and Saturdays until Jan. 22, visitors to the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx can enjoy a mile and a half of landscape similarly strung with thousands of LED bulbs for “NYGB Glow,” which also features ice sculpting, music and a night market. Tickets are $35 for adults and $20 for children and available at nybg.org.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins, Noah Weiland and Christina Jewett
title: Lifesaving Covid Treatments Face Rationing as Virus Surges Again
description: Scarce supplies and surging Covid cases have caused health officials, hospitals, doctors and patients to scramble for pills and infusions.
content: At the onset of the coronavirus pandemic in 2020, scarce ventilators and protective equipment faced strict rationing. Today, as the pandemic rages into its third year, another precious category of products is coming under tight controls: treatments to stave off severe Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: For One Last Season, Alia Shawkat Is the Life of ‘Search Party’
description: On this dark and demanding satire, whose final episodes arrive Friday on HBO Max, Shawkat learned that she was more than capable of holding her own.
content: In the time that Alia Shawkat has played Dory Sief, the perpetually imperiled protagonist of “Search Party,” the actress has been repeatedly put to the test. Over the first four seasons of this dark comedy series, Dory obsessively chased a woman she wrongly believed was missing; she was blackmailed; she committed murder; she was put on trial; she was abducted, only to escape and return to her kidnapper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Why Are Freakish Fish Washing Ashore in California?
description: An unusual number of deep-sea denizens washed up last year on Southern California’s beaches.
content: One morning in May, a fisherman happened upon an unsightly creature washed up on a beach in Southern California: Mouth agape, it had needlelike teeth, slick black skin and a bulbous appendage protruding from its head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Lawrence N. Brooks, 112, Oldest American WWII Veteran, Dies
description: He served in the largely African American 91st engineering unit at a time of segregation in the Army.
content: Lawrence N. Brooks, the oldest World War II veteran in the United States, who served his country in a segregated unit, died on Wednesday. He was 112.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Here is a schedule of events commemorating the Jan. 6 attack.
description: Speeches by President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris are part of the events to mark the anniversary of the attack on the Capitol.
content: 9 a.m. President Biden and Vice President Harris will deliver remarks in the National Statuary Hall of the U.S. Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Trachta
title: ‘And Just Like That’ Episode 6 Recap: Ponderings Aplenty
description: Carrie ponders a face-lift. Miranda ponders her next move. Charlotte ponders why everything seems to be changing without her.
content: “I just charged tomatoes,” Carrie once told her boyfriend Aidan Shaw (John Corbett) in the original “Sex and the City,” “I’m not in a position to buy an apartment.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: Three Recipes for Your Favorite Mushroom Varietals
description: New year, new mushroom recipes to cozy up to.
content: When I was a vegetarian in high school, I got so sick of badly prepared portobello mushrooms! Watery stuffed portobellos, fibrous grilled portobellos, dry portobello sandwiches, spongy portobello salads. I avoided them for a while, not realizing just how good they could be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Hochul’s Speech Is a Road Map to the Campaign That Lies Ahead
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul sought to exude decisiveness in crisis, previewing her efforts to run as the steady-hand candidate as she seeks her first full term.
content: As Gov. Kathy Hochul delivered her most consequential speech since becoming chief executive of New York, she did not discuss the contested Democratic primary she is navigating to retain her seat, nor did she mention the likelihood of an expensive general election against a well-funded Republican.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: What Is Happening With the 2022 Golden Globes?
description: A guide to everything we know  about the 79th annual Golden Globes on Sunday night.
content: First, the Golden Globes were going to go toe-to-toe with the Critic’s Choice Awards on Sunday night. Now, after the critics’ ceremony was postponed amid the Omicron surge, the Globes will have Sunday night all to themselves for a big, splashy …
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Rhode Island Man Operated ‘Ghost Gun’ Home Factory, U.S. Says
description: Robert Alcantara was arrested in the Bronx as he traveled to his home from Pennsylvania, where he bought parts to make guns that cannot be traced.
content: One day in November, law enforcement authorities observed a Providence, R.I., man buy the key components of nearly four dozen so-called ghost guns at a gun show in Morgantown, Pa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Judith Davidoff, Master of Long-Dormant Instruments, Dies at 94
description: A master of the viola da gamba and other stringed instruments, she was a central part of the early-music scene.
content: Judith Davidoff, who mastered an assortment of stringed instruments not widely played for centuries, especially the cello-like viola da gamba, and became a leading proponent and player of early music, died on Dec. 19 at her home in Manhattan. She was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Grinspan and Peter Manseau
title: It’s 2086. This Is What American History Could Look Like.
description: As curators at the Smithsonian’s National Museum of American History, we are regularly confronted by hard physical evidence of just how slippery the past can be.
content: This article is part of a collection on the events of Jan. 6, one year later. Read more in a note from Times Opinion’s politics editor Ezekiel Kweku in our Opinion Today newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Tampa Bay Buccaneers Cut Antonio Brown
description: It was the receiver’s fourth departure from an N.F.L. team in four seasons, and perhaps the end to his career.
content: Antonio Brown, bare-chested and flashing the peace sign, jogged off the field at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., on Sunday, leaving behind a football game, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and, possibly, his N.F.L. career. His premature exit — it was only the third quarter — was either an act of extreme subordination or a refusal to compromise his health, or, perhaps, both.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Chicago Closes School Abruptly In Labor Battle
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, January 6, 2022.
content: “We have a two-party system in Chicago: We have the regular Democratic Party — the Republican Party is almost nonexistent — then we have the Chicago Teachers Union.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: Murder Most English
description: In “Something to Hide,” Elizabeth George delivers another intelligent, intricate mystery starring Detective Inspector Thomas Lynley of New Scotland Yard.
content: It was with some trepidation that I began the 21st installment in Elizabeth George’s series featuring Detective Inspector Thomas Lynley and Detective Sgts. Barbara Havers and Winston Nkata of New Scotland Yard: Do these books have to be so infernally long? Every single one of them is a doorstop. But by the end of SOMETHING TO HIDE (Viking, 687 pp., $29), I leaned toward a grudging yes, though with reservations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold, Jeffery C. Mays and Andy Newman
title: Police to Step Up Patrol of New York Subway, Adams Says
description: As the subway tries to lure back riders, Mayor Eric Adams said that officers would more regularly patrol stations and trains.
content: New York City will require police officers to conduct more frequent and regular sweeps of the subway system and work with homeless outreach teams to reassure current riders and lure back more commuters to a transit system that needs them, Mayor Eric Adams and Gov. Kathy Hochul said in a joint announcement on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: Alice Trumbull Mason, Alone and With Friends
description: A poignant gallery show of the artist’s “Shutter Paintings” is paired with an exceptional Whitney exhibition of the forward-looking prints that she and her contemporaries made in days gone by.
content: One of the many new frontiers in art history today is abstract art by women. It’s not possible to say for sure, but I suspect we barely know what we don’t know. This thought has hit me often in the last few years, usually in big, jolting museum exhibitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allison Hope
title: Watching a Partner Change Is Hard. Accepting It Can Be Harder.
description: We don’t marry one person as much as we marry one version of a person. But accepting the person a partner may become can be more challenging.
content: The party-going partner now prefers chamomile tea on the couch. The lover of wanderlust has started to cling to routine. The big spender has become a frugal budgeter. Blond turns brown, turns gray, turns bald. Waistlines expand and contract. So do sex drives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: Rethinking more boosters
description: Experts say continually boosting is unrealistic, and doesn’t make sense scientifically.
content: A few months ago, my colleague Apoorva Mandavilli was reporting on the booster rollout when an expert mentioned to her the possibility of “immune exhaustion,” in which boosting too much could backfire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Are We Really Facing a Second Civil War?
description: It’s hard to imagine. But so is democracy’s salvation.
content: Barbara F. Walter, a political scientist at the University of California, San Diego, has interviewed many people who’ve lived through civil wars, and she told me they all say they didn’t see it coming. “They’re all surprised,” she said. “Even when, to somebody who studies it, it’s obvious years beforehand.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Bartlett
title: Mining of Lithium, Key to the Climate Fight, Faces New Scrutiny in Chile
description: Politicians have called for a pause in new mining contracts for lithium, which is in high demand for electric car batteries but is at the heart of a debate in Chile over mines, water rights and inequality.
content: SAN PEDRO DE ATACAMA, Chile — Plans to expand lithium mining in Chile, the world’s second largest producer, hit political roadblocks this week, raising new questions about supplies of a metal that is in high demand as the world transitions away from fossil fuels and toward renewable energy sources.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: N.F.L. Week 18 Predictions: Our Picks Against the Spread
description: Division rivalries should decide playoff seeding as the Eagles host the Cowboys, the 49ers try to extend their win streak to six against the Rams, and the Chargers and Raiders play the weekend’s only true elimination game.
content: Five teams — the Colts, Chargers, Ravens, Steelers and Raiders — are still mathematically alive for two remaining A.F.C. playoff spots, while only the 49ers and the Saints are competing for the N.F.C.’s final berth. With only divisional games on the schedule, though, long-eliminated teams can play spoiler to their rivals, adding a bit of drama beyond the start-them-or-rest-them debate over star players on top-seeded teams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Cable TV Is the New Landline
description: Old habits die hard. But technology can change entrenched ways of doing things slowly and then very quickly.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Dog Is Hailed as ‘Real-Life Lassie’ After Leading Police to Truck Crash
description: Two men lay unconscious on a frigid Vermont night until Tinsley, a Shiloh Shepherd, led the authorities back to the site of the wreck.
content: As Cam Laundry lay unconscious in the snowy woods near his battered pickup after a rollover crash, his dog Tinsley ran off into the icy Vermont night and returned with help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: ‘I Felt Angry’: Trapped Alone in the Capitol, He Watched the Riot Unfold
description: Wayne K. Williams, a top aide to the No. 5 House Democrat, was the only member of his staff in the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. He was barricaded in his office alone as mayhem reigned.
content: WASHINGTON — Wayne K. Williams, a senior adviser to Representative Hakeem Jeffries of New York, the No. 5 House Democrat, was the only staff member in his office on Jan. 6, barricaded in a room in the middle of the Capitol as the deadliest attack on the building in two centuries unfolded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘The Commando’ Review: Mickey Rourke, Still Standing, Barely
description: In this risible action thriller, a house on a dirt lot is catnip for criminals who know there’s a fortune under its floorboards.
content: A spectacularly atrocious, ostensible action thriller, “The Commando” is distinguished by an incompetence that extends even to locations. The title protagonist, a PTSD-riven agent for the Drug Enforcement Administration played by Michael Jai White, lives with his family in a house that sits on an unusually barren plot of land. The movie, directed by Asif Akbar, was shot in New Mexico, where xeriscaping is in vogue, but this place is, for all intents and purposes, a dirt lot. There’s not even a driveway, which makes things convenient for the baddies who stage a sodden, tedious home invasion near the movie’s end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Emmanuel Macron lashes out at the unvaccinated.
content: Using his harshest language yet about the unvaccinated — the French word he used is more vulgar — Emmanuel Macron, the French president, said he would not “throw them in prison” or “vaccinate them by force.” But he made it clear he meant to make their lives harder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: This week’s properties are in Clinton Hill, Murray Hill and Lincoln Square.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: She Spent Her Life Fighting for Equity for Women in Sports
description: Christine Grant, the Title IX pioneer who died in December, often lamented the historically poor treatment of female athletes, asking incredulously, “Can you imagine that?”
content: After surviving World War II as a girl in Scotland, sometimes zipped into a one-piece garment called a siren suit and hastened into a bomb shelter built by her father, Christine Grant took up sports. From that point, she often said, she could not imagine her life without them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: The G.O.P. Is Making ‘Critical Race Theory’ the New ‘Shariah Law’
description: Critical race theory is a boogeyman the right can use to activate and harness racist anti-otherness.
content: The protests of summer 2020 may have been not only some of the biggest in the country, but also some of the biggest in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Jessica Cheung, Rob Szypko, Rachel Quester, Eric Krupke, Diana Nguyen, Lisa Tobin, Chelsea Daniel, Marion Lozano and Corey Schreppel
title: Jan. 6, Part 2: Liz Cheney’s Battle Against the ‘Big Lie’
description: A conversation with the Republican House member about the Capitol riots and the state, and future, of the Republican Party.
content: This episode contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why the Nobel-Winning Economist Amartya Sen Recommends ‘King Lear’
description: “Sympathy and solidarity are qualities that people do need.”
content: “If I am forced to choose only one book for the president, it would be hard to leave out ‘King Lear,’” says the Nobel-winning economist Amartya Sen, whose forthcoming memoir is “Home in the World.” “Sympathy and solidarity are qualities that people do need.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Ethics Adviser Rebukes Boris Johnson Over Downing Street Decorations
description: The adviser said it was “plainly unsatisfactory” that he was not told that Mr. Johnson had petitioned a prominent donor to arrange financing for the makeover of his apartment.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson suffered a stinging rebuke from his ethics adviser on Thursday over the costly refurbishment of his Downing Street apartment, after the British leader blamed a change of cellphones for his failure to disclose messages about the makeover.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: How Corporate America Has Changed After the Capitol Attack
description: Business leaders promised a reckoning after the Jan. 6 riots. They’ve altered some practices, and returned to others.
content: On this morning a year ago, we did not know just how fragile American democracy would prove to be. The U.S. Capitol would soon become an unimaginable scene: A deadly riot by a mob encouraged by President Donald Trump and other Republicans objecting to their loss in the 2020 presidential election and seeking to overturn the result.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: Notes From the End of a Very Long Life
description: With the death of Ruth Willig at 98, a Times series on a set of the oldest New Yorkers — chronicled over seven years in 21 articles — offers their lessons on living with loss.
content: In late October, when the weather turned unseasonably warm, I called Ruth Willig to ask her to lunch. Ruth was almost 98, in an assisted living building in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, so when she didn’t pick up for a few days, I worried. Finally, she answered and said that someone at her building had tested positive for the coronavirus, so everyone was under lockdown for at least two weeks. Lunch, alas, was not possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden condemns Trump as Washington splits over legacy of Jan. 6 attack.
description: President Biden used the anniversary of the Capitol siege to deliver his most sustained and scathing repudiation of Donald J. Trump since taking office.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden denounced former President Donald J. Trump and his allies on Thursday for holding “a dagger at the throat of America” by promoting lies and violence as the nation’s capital fractured into sparring camps a year after the Jan. 6 mob assault on Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: One Year After the Jan. 6 Attack, Parler’s C.E.O. Grapples with Big Tech and Trump
description: George Farmer doubles down on his efforts to revive a right-leaning social media company that was taken offline a year ago.
content: After an angry mob attacked the Capitol last year and users on the right-leaning social network Parler organized, shared footage and called to “burn D.C. to the ground,” Kara Swisher grilled the platform’s co-founder and C.E.O., John Matze. The interview was cited in Apple’s decision to take Parler off its App store and Amazon’s decision to suspend web hosting service for Parler. Google also booted the platform off its Play Store. Parler effectively went offline because of these three moves, and Matze lost his job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: Oregon Says Nicholas Kristof Cannot Run for Governor
description: The secretary of state said that Mr. Kristof, a former New York Times columnist, did not meet the state’s three-year residency requirement.
content: Nicholas Kristof, a former New York Times columnist seeking to become the next governor of Oregon, does not qualify to run for the office this year because he failed to meet the state’s three-year residency requirement, state officials announced on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Kazakhstan’s huge Bitcoin mining industry is upended by unrest.
description: After the country’s largest telecommunications company shut off internet access throughout the country on Wednesday, processing activity on Bitcoin plunged.
content: Violent protests against the government in Kazakhstan led to intermittent internet shutdowns for a second day, as troops from a Russia-led military alliance arrived in the country to restore order. The lack of connectivity disrupted huge cryptocurrency mining operations in the country, which has become one of the world’s largest hubs for this activity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Stewart
title: Christian Nationalism Is One of Trump’s Most Powerful Weapons
description: And it is still being wielded in service of Trump’s fictions.
content: This article is part of a collection on the events of Jan. 6, one year later. Read more in a note from Times Opinion’s politics editor Ezekiel Kweku in our Opinion Today newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Is Thrilled Trump’s Finally Listening to Someone
description: Advisers told the former president to push his Jan. 6 news conference to a date that would draw less attention to a low point of his presidency. “So, every day of his presidency?” Stephen Colbert joked.
content: Welcome to the Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Jan. 6 and America’s Broken Spirit
description: The collapse of decency feeds the attacks on democracy.
content: “Things feel broken.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: What Do You Want to Investigate?
description: You may not be a student journalist, but you can still think about injustices or issues in your community that should be uncovered.
content: Note: This Student Opinion question, along with a related Lesson of the Day, will help prepare students for our live panel with Jodi Kantor and Megan Twohey on Jan. 27. Register here. We also invite students to send us video answers to this Student Opinion question here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Kyrie Irving returns to the court after refusing to be vaccinated.
description: Irving declined to be vaccinated for Covid-19 before the season, making him ineligible to play in New York City because of a local vaccine mandate at sports arenas that went into effect in September.
content: Kyrie Irving, the star Nets guard, made his regular-season debut against the Indiana Pacers on Wednesday night following the team’s surprise reversal of its policy to bar him from practices and road games until he received the coronavirus vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘This is really happening’: Times reporters discuss their experience outside the Capitol on Jan. 6.
description: A New York Times team was out on Jan. 6, 2021, to cover what was expected to be a modest “Stop the Steal” rally on the Ellipse.
content: A team was deployed on Jan. 6, 2021, to cover what was thought to be a modest “Stop the Steal” rally on the Ellipse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Starbucks union workers near Buffalo walk out over Covid concerns.
description: The walkout, involving about half a dozen employees, is planned to last the rest of the week.
content: With coronavirus cases surging across New York State, employees at the only company-owned Starbucks store that is unionized staged a walkout on Wednesday to protest what they say are unsafe working conditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘The 355’ Review: Exile in Bondville
description: Jessica Chastain, Penélope Cruz, Lupita Nyong’o, Diane Kruger and Fan Bingbing star in an espionage thriller that’s slick but banal.
content: Two centuries before James Bond 007, there was Agent 355, a lady spy on George Washington’s side during the American Revolutionary War who helped identify the turncoat Benedict Arnold. Her name was hidden from history, but her code number has been claimed by this slick and grim espionage flick that aspires to become an all-star, all-female franchise — the Spice Girls version of Bond. Jessica Chastain, a producer and star of the movie, even used Twitter to crowdsource casting suggestions for a “#BondBoy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Jan. 12, 2022
description: What are the supply and demand factors that affect a country’s vaccination rate?
content: Covid vaccination rates vary enormously by country. These differences are partially caused by supply issues, including the number of doses, cold storage while delivering vaccines and the availability of people to give the shots. However, they are also caused by demand issues, including religious and other personal vaccine hesitancies, mistrust of governments and skepticism about where their vaccines are coming from (such as the country of origin).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronique Greenwood
title: Every Pore on Your Face Is a Walled Garden
description: A close examination of human skin found that each pore had a single variety of bacteria living inside.
content: Your skin is home to a thousand kinds of bacteria, and the ways they contribute to healthy skin are still largely mysterious. This mystery may be getting even more complex: In a paper published Thursday in the journal Cell Host & Microbe, researchers studying the many varieties of Cutibacterium acnes bacteria on 16 human volunteers found that each pore was a world unto itself. Every pore contained just a single type of C. acnes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac
title: Lawsuit says Meta shares blame in the killing of a federal guard.
description: A lawsuit argued that individuals who sought to harm law enforcement officers were able to connect with one another on Facebook.
content: Facebook’s parent company, Meta Platforms, has been sued over the 2020 killing of a federal security guard, a move that aims to challenge a federal statute that shields websites and social media platforms from liability for what users post.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: 4 takeaways from the anniversary of the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
description: President Biden took a confrontational approach to his predecessor, who isn’t going away, and other takeaways from the commemoration events.
content: WASHINGTON — This anniversary of Jan. 6 marked a turning point for President Biden, who for much of his first year in office avoided direct confrontation with his predecessor, Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘A Hero’ Review: Debts No Honest Man Can Pay
description: In the latest film from the two-time Oscar winner Asghar Farhadi, a good Samaritan comes under suspicion.
content: “The last temptation is the greatest treason: to do the right deed for the wrong reason.” “A Hero,” the new film by the Iranian writer-director Asghar Farhadi, seems to circle around these lines from T.S. Eliot’s “Murder in the Cathedral,” spinning Eliot’s observation about morality into a squall of questions about ethics and motives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: That Vintage Dress on the Red Carpet? There’s More to the Story.
description: It’s awards season, and the big designer brands have some scrappy, pre-owned competition.
content: The red carpet is a financial exchange — the most high-profile of red carpets, at least. If the E! Network has at least one microphone-wielding staffer on standby, there is serious money on the table.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Winter TV: 20 Shows You Might Not Know Already
description: There’s a pileup of prestige series returning this season, from “Mrs. Maisel” to “Atlanta” to “Bridgerton.” This list is about the other shows. And “Law & Order.”
content: Thanks partly to the vagaries of Covid-19, there is an unusually large amount of prestige hitting the television schedule over the next three months — critical and audience favorites making triumphant returns after varying lengths of time. The safe and easy thing to do with a winter preview would be to fill it with those known quantities. But that wouldn’t be much fun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: The Best (and Worst) Places for Singles to Rent Studios
description: Where do the unattached contribute the smallest chunk of their paycheck to rent a studio apartment?
content: Have you considered a studio apartment? It’s a popular choice for those just starting out and looking to save money — and maybe to vacuum less often or take shorter walks to the fridge. Plus, without a roommate, privacy is abundant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove, Joel Wolfram and Campbell Robertson
title: Philadelphia House Fire Leaves 12 Dead, Including 8 Children
description: It was among the deadliest residential fires in the country in recent years. The mayor called it “one of the most tragic days in our city’s history.”
content: PHILADELPHIA — Neighbors, awakened by screams, looked out their windows at the cold dark morning. Flames were pouring out of the second-story windows of a rowhouse on 23rd Street as people on the block watched in horror.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: In Kazakhstan, Putin Again Seizes on Unrest to Try to Expand Influence
description: But a series of revolts against a pro-Russian strongman could also plant the seeds of rebellion at home, analysts say.
content: Long adept at stoking unrest in the West, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia sent troops to the Central Asian nation of Kazakhstan on Thursday to try to extinguish the latest in a series of dangerous fires to engulf the lands of the former Soviet Union, territory that Moscow views as its own sphere of influence but has struggled to keep calm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes and Christina Jewett
title: Emerging Data Raise Questions About Antigen Tests and Nasal Swabs
description: A new study adds to evidence that common rapid tests may fail to detect some Omicron cases in the first days of infection.
content: A small, new real-world study suggests that two widely used at-home antigen tests, the Abbott BinaxNOW and Quidel QuickVue, may fail to detect some Omicron infections even when people are carrying high levels of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: In His Return, a Nets Star Shows Why His Team Made an Exception
description: Kyrie Irving’s part-time status will be complicated — he still can’t play in home games — but his return drew praise from his team’s other stars.
content: The Nets find themselves in a basketball paradox: They have championship aspirations, yet it might be in their best interests to lose a few more games on the way to the playoffs — and play their way into a lower seed once they arrive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Does My Boyfriend Like Me, or Does He Like That I’m a Twin?
description: A reader wonders whether a friend’s suggestion might have some truth to it.
content: I’ve been seeing a nice guy since I moved to town this summer. From the beginning, he has been very interested in the fact that I have a twin sister. (She doesn’t live here.) When he invited me to spend Christmas with his family, he invited me to bring my twin. After I said she couldn’t make it, he told me his mom was worried about having too many people at the house while Omicron surged. He asked if I could come another time. My friend says he’s clearly a creep with a thing for twins. Your thoughts?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith and Robert Chiarito
title: ‘An Untenable Situation’: Chicagoans in Limbo After Schools Abruptly Close
description: Teachers voted to stop going to school amid a standoff between Mayor Lori Lightfoot and the Chicago Teachers Union, which called for more virus safeguards.
content: CHICAGO — Parents across Chicago raced to find child care on Wednesday morning after jarring news: Classes in the nation’s third-largest public school district were canceled. The teachers’ union and Mayor Lori Lightfoot’s administration had failed to agree on how to keep schools open during an Omicron-fueled virus surge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Virginia Democrats Aim to Block Trump’s E.P.A. Chief From State Agency
description: In Virginia, cabinet nominees are rarely blocked. But the Republican governor-elect’s choice of Andrew Wheeler to be natural resources secretary has alarmed Democrats.
content: WASHINGTON — A rare confirmation battle is brewing around the nomination of Andrew Wheeler, who ran the Environmental Protection Agency under President Donald J. Trump, to take a similar role in an incoming Republican state administration in Virginia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: fluctuate
description: This word has appeared in 97 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margalit Fox
title: Peter Bogdanovich, 82, Director Whose Career Was a Hollywood Drama, Dies
description: Within one decade, the ’70s, he was transformed from one of the most celebrated of filmmakers, notably for “The Last Picture Show,” into one of the most ostracized.
content: Peter Bogdanovich, who parlayed his ardor for Golden Age cinema into the direction of acclaimed films like “The Last Picture Show” and “Paper Moon,” only to have his professional reputation tarnished in one of Hollywood’s most conspicuous falls from grace, died early Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: A Live Panel for Students: How Investigative Journalism Works
description: An opportunity to hear from, and ask questions of, the journalists who helped ignite the #MeToo movement.
content: In October 2017, New York Times journalists Jodi Kantor and Megan Twohey broke the story of the Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein’s alleged sexual misconduct. Their reporting helped ignite the #MeToo movement and initiate policy changes around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Republicans and Democrats come together in Atlanta to remember Senator Isakson on Jan. 6.
description: On a day that amplified political divisions, lawmakers from both parties gathered in an Atlanta church to honor one of the Senate’s great champions of bipartisanship.
content: ATLANTA — On a day when Washington’s partisan divide felt as deep as it has in decades, lawmakers from both parties gathered in an Atlanta church on Thursday to honor one of the U.S. Senate’s great champions of bipartisanship, Johnny Isakson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Rosenberg, Jim Rutenberg and Michael M. Grynbaum
title: The Next Big Lies: Jan. 6 Was No Big Deal, or a Left-Wing Plot
description: How revisionist histories of Jan. 6 picked up where the “stop the steal” campaign left off, warping beliefs about what transpired at the Capitol.
content: It was mere hours after a mob spurred on by the “stop the steal” lies of President Donald J. Trump had attacked the United States Capitol, and already new lies were taking hold in the nearby streets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siddhartha Mitter
title: In the Lower Ninth Ward, an Artist Renews His Purpose
description: Kevin Beasley was invited to create an installation in New Orleans for a few months. Instead he bought land, and met his neighbors.
content: NEW ORLEANS — The cookout in the new garden, guests agreed, upheld the cultural and convivial traditions of the Lower Ninth Ward.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 6, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Jan. 6, 2022.
content: An article on Tuesday about 12 things The Times’s critics are looking forward to in 2022 misstated the title of the debut stand-up special from Taylor Tomlinson. It is “Quarter-Life Crisis,” not “Quarter-Life Special.”
